results.headline: Review: ‘A War’ Tracks a Conflict from Battle Zone to Court
results.summary_short: In this Danish film by Tobias Lindholm, an Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film, a commander faces trial after ordering an attack on civilians in Afghanistan.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A War

results.headline: Review: In ‘Cabin Fever,’ the Flesh-Eating Virus Strikes Again
results.summary_short: The director Travis Z. remakes Eli Roth’s 2002 film about vacationing post-adolescents who fall victim to a viral nightmare.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cabin Fever

results.headline: Review: In ‘Bad Hurt,’ a Staten Island Family Struggles
results.summary_short: This drama, set in 1999, features post-traumatic stress disorder and other problems that are not easily solved.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bad Hurt

results.headline: Review: ‘Already Tomorrow in Hong Kong,’ a Meet-Cute Romance
results.summary_short: Written and directed by Emily Ting, this film tells of two Americans who run into each other on the streets of a glittering city.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Already Tomorrow in Hong Kong

results.headline: Review: ‘Glassland,’ the Brittle Territory of Love and Addiction
results.summary_short: Alcohol is a dependable friend for a woman (Toni Collette) who has been abandoned and disappointed by life and has let others down in turn.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Glassland

results.headline: Review: ‘How to Be Single’ Is Another Lonely-Hearts Adaptation
results.summary_short: This adventure, which stars Dakota Johnson, flops even with Leslie Mann and Rebel Wilson hard at work being funny.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How to Be Single

results.headline: Review: In ‘Zoolander 2,’ All Is Still Vanity
results.summary_short: Ben Stiller’s Derek Zoolander, 15 years later, is forever pursing his lips, striking poses and practicing his telekinetic blue-steel glare.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zoolander 2

results.headline: Review: ‘Deadpool,’ a Sardonic Supervillain on a Kill Mission
results.summary_short: This eager-to-please comic-book movie, starring Ryan Reynolds and directed by Tim Miller, is the latest entry in the Marvel universe.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Deadpool

results.headline: Review: ‘Regression’: Memory Isn’t All It’s Cracked Up to Be
results.summary_short: The film, directed by Alejandro Amenábar and starring Emma Watson and Ethan Hawke, finds a detective investigating a child abuse case.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Regression

results.headline: Review: In ‘I Knew Her Well,’ Stefania Sandrelli Reaches for la Dolce Vita
results.summary_short: In this restored 1965 film from the writer-director Antonio Pietrangeli, a would-be starlet fitfully ascends the social stratum.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Knew Her Well

results.headline: Review: ‘4th Man Out,’ a Film About Friendship and Coming Out
results.summary_short: Adam, a mechanic in his 20s who has recently come out, tries dating apps with the encouragement of his three lifelong buddies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 4th Man Out

results.headline: Review: In ‘Fort Buchanan,’ Making Love and War
results.summary_short: Benjamin Crotty’s film, set at a French fort, follows a young woman, her two fathers and all the amorous military spouses and lovers around them.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fort Buchanan

results.headline: Review: ‘The Club’ Sees the World Through the Eyes of Damaged Souls
results.summary_short: Pablo Larraín’s film brings the viewer into an uncomfortable state of intimacy with disgraced priests who are perpetrators of hideous crimes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Club

results.headline: Review: ‘Misconduct’ Stars Josh Duhamel and Anthony Hopkins in a Tale of Corporate Evil
results.summary_short: This action thriller, the directorial debut of Shintaro Shimosawa, also features Al Pacino as a lawyer caught in a power struggle with a corrupt pharmaceutical executive.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Misconduct

results.headline: Review: In ‘Tumbledown,’ a Book Is the Third Party in a Love Triangle
results.summary_short: Rebecca Hall plays the young grieving widow of an acclaimed indie-folk singer and Jason Sudeikis his brash biographer in this dramedy directed by Sean Mewshaw.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tumbledown

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Choice,’ a Sudsy Romance That Was Meant to Be
results.summary_short: Based on a book by Nicholas Sparks, the film stars Teresa Palmer and Benjamin Walker as a pair who fall in love amid rain-soaked trysts and ocean sunsets.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Choice

results.headline: Review: ‘Southbound’ Tells Five Horror Tales, All Set on a Desolate Highway
results.summary_short: This anthology film, by the directors Roxanne Benjamin, David Bruckner, Patrick Horvath and the collective Radio Silence, presents characters who need to escape (and can’t).

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Southbound

results.headline: Review: ‘The Pack’ Pits a Family Against Vicious Wild Dogs
results.summary_short: Nick Robertson’s Australian film, set on a remote sheep farm in the Outback, is in some ways reminiscent of “Cujo,” but offers far less plot.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pack

results.headline: Review: ‘Pride and Prejudice and Zombies’; More Tea, Dear?
results.summary_short: In this undead ravishing of the Jane Austen novel, Elizabeth Bennet must deal with creatures much, much worse than Mr. Darcy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pride and Prejudice and Zombies

results.headline: Review: In ‘Hail, Caesar!’ the Coens Revisit Old Hollywood
results.summary_short: Joel and Ethan Coen meander in and around their Tinseltown dream factory cracking jokes in a film set a decade after Barton Fink’s meltdown.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hail, Caesar!
